meteorology.overall_conditions_summary: For Rockford, MI on Tuesday 2/3/2026, the forecast is cold (around 21–25°F daytime) but quiet: no accumulating snow or precip and light winds. The only meaningful school-transport risk signal in the provided data is potential fog/freezing fog and reduced visibility near/after midnight and possibly around early morning, which could create localized slick spots on untreated surfaces. With Michigan winter operations and no active snowfall at bus time, this setup strongly favors a normal school day. Estimated snow-day/closure probability: ~5–10% (mostly for localized freezing fog/black-ice/visibility issues rather than snow).

similar_weather_patterns.pattern_description: Post-storm/arctic high pressure build-in: previous day snow/freezing drizzle ends, then a cold, quiet, mostly-overcast day with light winds. Typical outcome is NORMAL school operations because roads improve steadily once precipitation stops.

‘Cold + low visibility (fog/freezing fog) without new snow’: commonly produces localized slick spots (bridges/overpasses, shaded rural roads) and slower buses, but rarely a full-district closure in West Michigan unless the freezing fog occurs during the morning commute and is widespread/dense.

‘Lingering impacts day’ after a marginal snow/ice event (1–2 inches + freezing drizzle the day before): closures depend more on overnight refreeze and whether secondary roads were treated. In Michigan this is more likely to cause delays than full closures, especially if winds are light and temps are in the teens/low 20s.

seasonal_context.typical_conditions_for_date: Early February in Rockford (Kent County) is peak winter resilience season: districts are fully in “winter mode,” road commissions are staffed, and the community is accustomed to subfreezing mornings. A dry day with temps in the low 20s and light winds is typically very manageable.
unusual_factors: No new snow/rain is forecast on Tue 2026-02-03 (0"), which strongly suppresses closure risk.
Very cold morning/overnight lows (down near 3°F) can ‘lock in’ any untreated slush/film from Monday and can create black ice on back roads.

Visibility signals are the only real wildcard: several hours overnight show extremely low vis values, and late-night freezing fog is explicitly indicated (23:00). If that kind of dense freezing fog were instead present 06:00–08:00, risk would jump.

local_microclimates: Rockford sits in a river-valley/lowland setting (Rogue River area) where fog and shallow cold-air pooling can be more common than on higher, more open ground.
Rural-to-suburban bus routes north and east of town can include low spots and tree-lined/shaded stretches that hold ice longer, especially after a freezing drizzle event.
Bridges/overpasses on main routes (and any untreated subdivision streets) are the first places to glaze when temps are in the teens or single digits.
infrastructure_considerations: Kent County/West Michigan has strong plowing and salting capacity; after precipitation ends, main roads typically improve quickly.
Michigan decision-making is commute-condition driven: if it’s dry but slick in pockets, districts often choose a DELAY rather than a full closure.
Because Tuesday’s winds are light (generally <10 mph), blowing/drifting snow is not a factor; that removes one of the classic closure triggers.
location_specific_factors.elevation_impact: Small elevation differences around Rockford matter mainly for fog/black-ice pockets (low areas) rather than large snowfall gradients.

history.confidence_assessment: Overall snow-day (full closure) risk for Rockford on Tue 2026-02-03 is LOW given the forecast is dry (0" new snow) with light winds. Historically in Michigan, ‘dry but cold’ days almost never close schools by themselves; the only meaningful pathway to a closure here is residual slickness from Monday’s snow/freezing drizzle plus overnight refreeze—more often a delay than a closure. I’d calibrate full-closure probability around ~5–12% (most likely near the lower end if roads are treated Monday evening), with a higher tail (~15–25%) only if dense freezing fog/black ice is widespread specifically during 6:30–7:30 AM bus time.

safety_recommendations: Snow day probability driver is NOT new snowfall on Tuesday (forecast shows 0”). The real question is what Monday’s wintry mix (snow + freezing drizzle/freezing rain) leaves behind by Tuesday morning.

Primary roads (M-44/US-131 corridors, major arterials): expect mostly passable Tuesday morning if MDOT treated Monday evening/night. Watch for isolated black ice on bridges, ramps, and untreated turn lanes because temps are well below freezing (low near 3°F).

Secondary/rural roads and subdivisions: higher risk of slick patches from refreeze of Monday’s moisture and from any compacted snow/ice not fully scraped. Bus routes on gravel/low-priority roads are the most likely “problem pockets.”

Visibility is the biggest Tuesday-specific flag: the hourly forecast shows several near-zero visibility hours overnight/early morning (00:00–04:00) and reduced visibility again around 07:00–08:00. Even without snow, this suggests fog/low stratus; if it’s freezing fog, it can also deposit a light glaze on untreated surfaces.

Bus operations: have first-run drivers report in by ~5:45–6:15 AM Tuesday with special attention to bridges, shaded curves, and hill stops. If multiple buses report slide-throughs or stopping-distance issues, consider a delay over a closure (Michigan can usually operate if it’s patchy).

Pedestrian risk: with temps in the teens/low 20s and wind chills around ~15°F during the morning commute, cold is uncomfortable but not a closure trigger. Main hazard for walkers is slick sidewalks/driveways from Monday’s icing/refreeze.
Parking lots/sidewalks at buildings: plan for spot salting early. Lots often lag road treatment and can stay glassy in low spots.

Decision guidance for Rockford (Tuesday 2/3): If roads were heavily iced Monday afternoon/evening and temps stay below freezing all night, a 2-hour delay is the most plausible operational adjustment. Full closure would be unlikely unless there is widespread freezing fog glaze or widespread untreated ice on secondary roads.

What would push risk higher by 5:30–6:00 AM Tuesday: confirmed freezing fog with glaze, multiple crash/slide-offs reported locally, or widespread “shiny” roads on neighborhood streets despite treatment.

timeline.conditions_start: Overnight Mon→Tue (2026-02-03 00:00): refreeze and patchy fog/freezing fog potential develops; worst visibility most likely ~01:00–04:00

final.decision_rationale:
All four core experts (meteorology/history/safety/news) converged tightly (7–9%, avg ~8%) on a low full-closure risk for Rockford on Tue 2/3 because the forecast shows no new snow/ice during bus hours and light winds, giving road crews ample time to recover from Monday’s wintry mix. The main plausible failure mode is a ‘cleanup + deep refreeze’ morning: any Monday drizzle/moisture that wasn’t fully treated can freeze hard with an overnight low near 3°F, creating patchy black ice—more likely on secondary/rural roads and bridges than on trunklines/major arterials. Visibility is the biggest wildcard: the meteorology clarification indicates the worst fog/visibility restriction is more likely 1–4 AM, with only a smaller possible dip near 7–8 AM; that timing makes a district-wide cancellation unlikely (a delay is the more typical Michigan response if pockets are slick). 

Potential conflict resolved: Web verification shows a large Weather.com vs WeatherAPI temperature/feels-like mismatch, but even the colder Weather.com scenario (~0°F with -13 to -16°F feels-like) does NOT cross the ≤-20°F automatic-closure rule, and winds are light. Therefore, temperature uncertainty alone doesn’t justify a high closure probability; it mainly increases refreeze persistence and supports a ‘watch for delay’ posture rather than a full snow day.

Recommendation (operational): OPEN with monitoring as the base case; the realistic operational adjustment, if needed, is a 2-hour delay (not a closure) if early bus checks find widespread untreated ice or freezing fog glaze during 6–8 AM.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Most likely: School OPEN (normal schedule). Patchy slick spots on bridges/secondary roads; buses run with caution.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Normal operations; slower morning travel in pockets. Minor delays possible on some routes.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: 2-hour delay due to widespread patchy black ice and/or persistent freezing fog into 6–8 AM causing multiple bus safety issues.
alternative_scenarios.impact: Reduced morning crash risk; gives treatment time and daylight/visibility improvement.

alternative_scenarios.scenario: Full closure (snow day) triggered by widespread glaze/near-zero visibility at bus time or a sudden outage cluster affecting facilities/traffic signals.
alternative_scenarios.impact: District-wide cancellation; would require conditions notably worse than current guidance suggests.

for_schools: Base plan: OPEN, but run early AM road/bus route checks (first reports by ~05:45–06:15).
Set clear triggers for a 2-hour delay: multiple bus slide-throughs, widespread ‘shiny’ neighborhood streets despite treatment, or confirmed dense freezing fog persisting into 06:30–08:00.
Prioritize salting/traction at building entrances, parking lots, and known icy bus-loop/sidewalk trouble spots (lots often lag road conditions).
Communications: message families tonight that Tuesday looks like a cleanup/refreeze morning; emphasize slower travel and that a delay decision (if needed) would come early.
for_residents: Assume black ice is possible Tuesday morning even if roads look dry; slow down on bridges/ramps and shaded roads.
If you can, build extra time for the 6:30–8:00 AM drive; use headlights in fog/low stratus.
Check district notifications early (before ~6 AM) in case a delay is called due to localized conditions.
for_authorities: Focus overnight/early AM treatment on bridges, ramps, hills, and known refreeze corridors; salt effectiveness may be reduced in single-digit temps, so consider abrasives where appropriate.
Monitor and message any freezing fog/visibility hazards that persist into the commute window.
If available, push any real-time road-condition advisories (MDOT/KCRC) to public channels before 6 AM.

positions.rationale: Meteorologically, Tuesday (2026-02-03) is a classic post-event high-pressure/cold overcast day: cold but quiet, with no accumulating snow or ice forecast during the school commute window. That strongly suppresses full-closure odds in West Michigan. The pathway to a closure is indirect: residual slickness from Monday’s snow/freezing drizzle + strong overnight refreeze, potentially compounded by dense (freezing) fog reducing visibility and adding a light glaze. With winds light and no precip forecast, I’d expect at most localized hazardous spots and possibly a delay in worst-case verification, not a district-wide cancellation. Hence a low but non-zero probability.
keyFactors: No new precip on Tue 2026-02-03 in the provided hourly forecast (0.00" precip / 0 cm snow; 0% snow chance) — removes the main closure trigger.
Light winds (max ~8 mph) and no blowing/drifting snow risk.

Temperatures remain below freezing all day (high ~25°F, low advertised as ~3°F) → any residual moisture from Mon 2026-02-02 can refreeze into black ice, especially on untreated secondary roads/bridges.

Visibility is the only Tuesday-specific meteorological wildcard: multiple hours show very low/zero visibility, and “freezing fog” is explicitly forecast late evening; if fog/freezing fog is actually widespread near 6–8 AM, it can meaningfully impact buses.
Active NWS statement is for Monday morning and expires at noon Monday; it’s a “leftover impacts” setup rather than an active-storm Tuesday.

positions.rationale: As the history specialist, I’m anchoring on how similar setups typically play out in Rockford/Kent County: the day *after* a minor snow/freezing-drizzle event, when precip ends and winds stay light, closures are uncommon because main roads recover quickly and districts can manage isolated slick spots with slower bus speeds or a delay. The forecast for Tue 2026-02-03 is dry, light wind, and cold—conditions that suppress full-closure decisions. The realistic pathway to a closure is not snowfall but widespread refreeze/black ice plus dense freezing fog during the AM commute; given the data’s fog signal is strongest overnight/late rather than clearly centered on 6–8 AM, I keep the closure probability in the high-single-digits.
keyFactors: No new precip forecast for Tue 2026-02-03 (0" snow / 0" precip). Historically in West Michigan, “dry/cold cleanup day” almost never produces a full closure by itself.

This is a classic post-event day: Mon 2026-02-02 has light snow + freezing drizzle risk; Tue becomes cold/quiet. Historically that pattern yields normal operations or, at most, a 2-hour delay if there’s overnight refreeze on secondary roads.

Temps drop very low by late Tue (forecast min ~3°F), which increases the chance that any leftover moisture from Monday becomes black ice—more of a delay trigger than a full closure trigger in Kent County’s typical winter-response context.

Visibility is the only meaningful wildcard in the Tuesday dataset: multiple hours show extremely low visibility values and “freezing fog” appears late (23:00). If dense fog/ice glaze shifts into the 6–8 AM bus window and is widespread, closure odds increase—but that’s not clearly indicated at the exact commute window.
Peak-winter resilience: early February districts and road crews are operationally prepared; absent active snowfall/wind/drifting, they tend to run buses cautiously rather than cancel district-wide.

positions.rationale: From a safety standpoint, a full snow day on Tuesday 2026-02-03 looks unlikely because there’s no active snowfall/ice during the bus window and winds are light—meaning road crews have time to treat and conditions generally improve. The realistic failure mode is widespread refreeze/black ice from Monday’s wintry mix plus dense (possibly freezing) fog near the morning commute, which would elevate crash/slide-off risk and could force at least a delay. Given Michigan’s typical tolerance for patchy slickness and the absence of a new-storm signal, I land at ~9% for a full closure (with a notably higher probability of a delay than a closure).
keyFactors: No new precip on Tue 2026-02-03 (0" snow / 0 precip) and light winds (max ~8 mph): that strongly suppresses full-closure risk.

Primary safety risk is *residual* impacts from Mon 2026-02-02 (snow + possible freezing drizzle/freezing rain per alert): any leftover moisture/slush will refreeze hard with a Tue min near 3°F, creating black ice on bridges, ramps, shaded curves, and untreated subdivision/rural segments.

Visibility is the biggest Tuesday-morning operational wildcard: the hourly data shows several hours with near-zero/very low visibility overnight into early morning (00:00–04:00 and again near 07:00–08:00). If that is freezing fog near the commute window, it can both reduce stopping sight distance and deposit a light glaze on untreated pavement.

Rockford/Kent County winter ops capacity + the “day after” dynamic: this setup more commonly produces *delays* and “slow routes” rather than district-wide closure, unless multiple bus-route problem pockets are widespread at 5:30–6:30 AM.
Cold itself (even wind chills in the teens or modestly below 0°F) is generally not a closure trigger here absent extreme wind chills; pedestrian cold risk is secondary to slip/vehicle braking risk.

positions.rationale: As the NEWS specialist, I weight *actionable public signals* (district postings, neighboring district decisions, outage reports, event cancellations) alongside the forecast. For Tuesday, February 3, 2026, those signals are notably absent: no closure/delay announcements found and no clear neighboring-district “early call” pattern. With the provided forecast indicating no new snow/precip and light winds, a full closure is unlikely. The remaining credible risk is a post-event refreeze/black ice scenario from Monday’s snow/freezing drizzle plus potentially poor visibility/freezing fog around commute time—conditions that more often trigger a delay than a closure in this region. Net: low single-digit-to-low-teens risk; I’m landing at 7% for a full snow day (closure).
keyFactors: **No Tuesday storm signal in the forecast feed**: For Tue 2026-02-03, WeatherAPI shows 0" snow / 0 precip all day and light winds (<10 mph). That removes the usual closure drivers (active snow, drifting, rapid deterioration during bus time).

**News / district signaling is quiet**: No Rockford Public Schools (or nearby districts like Forest Hills, Cedar Springs, Sparta, Lowell) closure/delay messaging surfaced for Tue 2/3 in the provided scan; no “domino” early calls or strong public-facing buzz.

**Residual-impact risk is real but usually produces delays, not full closures**: NWS statement for Mon 2/2 highlights light snow + possible freezing drizzle. With Tue morning lows near ~3°F, any untreated moisture can refreeze into black ice—more consistent with a 2-hour delay than a full snow day.

**Visibility wildcard**: The hourly feed shows near-zero visibility at several overnight hours and explicitly “freezing fog” late night. If dense fog/glaze shifts into the 6–8 AM commute window and is widespread, closure odds rise—but right now that’s the only meaningful pathway.
**Infrastructure posture**: West Michigan/Kent County typically clears arterials quickly; with a dry Tuesday, operational capacity generally beats back post-storm impacts by the morning commute.

debates.challenge: No closure signals are helpful, but absence of evidence isn’t evidence of absence—especially because many districts decide pre-dawn. Consider weighting ‘no announcement’ lightly and focusing more on road-condition confirmation channels (MDOT/Kent Co updates) if available.

debates.topic: The WEBWEATHERVERIFIER notes a major temperature mismatch between WeatherAPI and Weather.com (possibly date/location context errors). If the colder scenario is real *and* coincides with freezing fog, black-ice risk rises. We need reconciliation, or at least an agreed conservative scenario for decision-making.
debates.challenge: The WEBWEATHERVERIFIER notes a major temperature mismatch between WeatherAPI and Weather.com (possibly date/location context errors). If the colder scenario is real *and* coincides with freezing fog, black-ice risk rises. We need reconciliation, or at least an agreed conservative scenario for decision-making.

debates.topic: The Tuesday hourly forecast shows *very* low/near-zero visibility for multiple hours. I want a clearer interpretation: is this actually dense fog/freezing fog expected during 06:00–08:00, or is it an artifact/poorly calibrated visibility field? If it verifies as dense freezing fog at commute time, closure/delay risk increases materially.
debates.challenge: The Tuesday hourly forecast shows *very* low/near-zero visibility for multiple hours. I want a clearer interpretation: is this actually dense fog/freezing fog expected during 06:00–08:00, or is it an artifact/poorly calibrated visibility field? If it verifies as dense freezing fog at commute time, closure/delay risk increases materially.

debates.topic: Historical pattern guidance is helpful, but it may underweight the combination of (a) freezing drizzle residue + (b) hard overnight lows (~3°F) + (c) potential dense fog in a river/lowland setting. Those three together can turn ‘patchy’ into ‘widespread’ quickly, especially on untreated neighborhood streets and bus turnarounds.
debates.challenge: Historical pattern guidance is helpful, but it may underweight the combination of (a) freezing drizzle residue + (b) hard overnight lows (~3°F) + (c) potential dense fog in a river/lowland setting. Those three together can turn ‘patchy’ into ‘widespread’ quickly, especially on untreated neighborhood streets and bus turnarounds.

debates.topic: No closure posts found is a weak negative signal because many districts decide pre-dawn. Also, lack of indexed ‘buzz’ doesn’t capture private/local FB groups where road conditions are often shared. I’d avoid leaning too heavily on this as reassurance.
debates.challenge: No closure posts found is a weak negative signal because many districts decide pre-dawn. Also, lack of indexed ‘buzz’ doesn’t capture private/local FB groups where road conditions are often shared. I’d avoid leaning too heavily on this as reassurance.

debates.topic: The forecast shows several hours of **0-mile visibility** overnight and even “freezing fog,” but the met summary treats it as a secondary factor. Can we pin down whether the low-vis period overlaps **6–8 AM** and whether it’s fog vs. data artifact? That timing is the difference between ‘minor’ and ‘meaningful’ operational risk.
debates.challenge: The forecast shows several hours of **0-mile visibility** overnight and even “freezing fog,” but the met summary treats it as a secondary factor. Can we pin down whether the low-vis period overlaps **6–8 AM** and whether it’s fog vs. data artifact? That timing is the difference between ‘minor’ and ‘meaningful’ operational risk.

debates.topic: Safety assessment implies a fairly broad ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact. I agree on black-ice potential, but I’d challenge whether that risk justifies a *closure* versus a *delay* given (a) no new precip Tue and (b) typical treatment/plowing capacity. Please separate “delay probability” from “closure probability.”
debates.challenge: Safety assessment implies a fairly broad ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact. I agree on black-ice potential, but I’d challenge whether that risk justifies a *closure* versus a *delay* given (a) no new precip Tue and (b) typical treatment/plowing capacity. Please separate “delay probability” from “closure probability.”

debates.topic: Historical rates cited (8–18%) look plausible, but they mix patterns that often produce **delays** with true **full closures**. For calibration, do those rates represent *any disruption* (delay/closure) or *closure-only*? If closure-only, they may be a bit high for a dry day.
debates.challenge: Historical rates cited (8–18%) look plausible, but they mix patterns that often produce **delays** with true **full closures**. For calibration, do those rates represent *any disruption* (delay/closure) or *closure-only*? If closure-only, they may be a bit high for a dry day.

debates.topic: Our own news input is thin and partially low-relevance. The biggest concern is the **WebWeatherVerifier discrepancy** (WeatherAPI vs Weather.com temps/wind chills). Even if wind chill isn’t a closure trigger here, that mismatch signals we may be looking at the wrong date/location in one source. We should prioritize confirming NWS point forecast for Rockford, MI for Tue 2/3 before anyone increases confidence.

confidenceJourney.shiftReason: Meteorologically, Tuesday (2026-02-03) is a classic post-event high-pressure/cold overcast day: cold but quiet, with no accumulating snow or ice forecast during the school commute window. That strongly suppresses full-closure odds in West Michigan. The pathway to a closure is indirect: residual slickness from Monday’s snow/freezing drizzle + strong overnight refreeze, potentially compounded by dense (freezing) fog reducing visibility and adding a light glaze. With winds light and no precip forecast, I’d expect at most localized hazardous spots and possibly a delay in worst-case verification, not a district-wide cancellation. Hence a low but non-zero probability.

As the history specialist, I’m anchoring on how similar setups typically play out in Rockford/Kent County: the day *after* a minor snow/freezing-drizzle event, when precip ends and winds stay light, closures are uncommon because main roads recover quickly and districts can manage isolated slick spots with slower bus speeds or a delay. The forecast for Tue 2026-02-03 is dry, light wind, and cold—conditions that suppress full-closure decisions. The realistic pathway to a closure is not snowfall but widespread refreeze/black ice plus dense freezing fog during the AM commute; given the data’s fog signal is strongest overnight/late rather than clearly centered on 6–8 AM, I keep the closure probability in the high-single-digits.

From a safety standpoint, a full snow day on Tuesday 2026-02-03 looks unlikely because there’s no active snowfall/ice during the bus window and winds are light—meaning road crews have time to treat and conditions generally improve. The realistic failure mode is widespread refreeze/black ice from Monday’s wintry mix plus dense (possibly freezing) fog near the morning commute, which would elevate crash/slide-off risk and could force at least a delay. Given Michigan’s typical tolerance for patchy slickness and the absence of a new-storm signal, I land at ~9% for a full closure (with a notably higher probability of a delay than a closure).

As the NEWS specialist, I weight *actionable public signals* (district postings, neighboring district decisions, outage reports, event cancellations) alongside the forecast. For Tuesday, February 3, 2026, those signals are notably absent: no closure/delay announcements found and no clear neighboring-district “early call” pattern. With the provided forecast indicating no new snow/precip and light winds, a full closure is unlikely. The remaining credible risk is a post-event refreeze/black ice scenario from Monday’s snow/freezing drizzle plus potentially poor visibility/freezing fog around commute time—conditions that more often trigger a delay than a closure in this region. Net: low single-digit-to-low-teens risk; I’m landing at 7% for a full snow day (closure).

keyDisagreements.topic: Be careful not to overweight “no announcement found” as evidence of no closure. Most districts decide very early morning; lack of a post on Feb 2 doesn’t strongly constrain Feb 3 outcomes. It’s supportive but weak.
positions: Be careful not to overweight “no announcement found” as evidence of no closure. Most districts decide very early morning; lack of a post on Feb 2 doesn’t strongly constrain Feb 3 outcomes. It’s supportive but weak.

keyDisagreements.topic: Your ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact seems plausible, but it implicitly assumes widespread freezing fog/near-zero vis during 6–8 AM. The provided Tue hourly data shows low/zero vis mostly overnight, with vis improving to 1–6 miles around 6–9 AM. If that improvement verifies, risk should be downgraded toward “low to moderate.”
positions: Your ‘moderate’ morning-commute impact seems plausible, but it implicitly assumes widespread freezing fog/near-zero vis during 6–8 AM. The provided Tue hourly data shows low/zero vis mostly overnight, with vis improving to 1–6 miles around 6–9 AM. If that improvement verifies, risk should be downgraded toward “low to moderate.”

keyDisagreements.topic: Your upper-tail scenario (15–25%) hinges on dense freezing fog during 6:30–7:30 AM; agree on the mechanism, but given the current hourly visibility trend (improving after sunrise) and zero precip, that tail should be treated as low-likelihood unless we see confirmation tonight of persistent fog into dawn.
positions: Your upper-tail scenario (15–25%) hinges on dense freezing fog during 6:30–7:30 AM; agree on the mechanism, but given the current hourly visibility trend (improving after sunrise) and zero precip, that tail should be treated as low-likelihood unless we see confirmation tonight of persistent fog into dawn.

keyDisagreements.topic: The Weather.com vs WeatherAPI temperature mismatch is large. However, even the colder scenario (near 0°F) is not, by itself, a typical Michigan closure trigger unless paired with widespread ice/fog. We should focus reconciliation on: (a) actual Tue 6–8 AM visibility/fog potential and (b) whether any freezing drizzle occurs late Mon that could glaze before the deep cold.
positions: The Weather.com vs WeatherAPI temperature mismatch is large. However, even the colder scenario (near 0°F) is not, by itself, a typical Michigan closure trigger unless paired with widespread ice/fog. We should focus reconciliation on: (a) actual Tue 6–8 AM visibility/fog potential and (b) whether any freezing drizzle occurs late Mon that could glaze before the deep cold.

keyDisagreements.topic: The Tue 2/3 hourly visibility values hit near-zero for several overnight hours; I’m not convinced we’ve translated that into an actionable “commute window” risk. Can you clarify whether the lowest vis is expected 6–8 AM vs. primarily midnight–4 AM? The closure vs delay distinction hinges on that timing.

Can you clarify whether the lowest vis is expected 6–8 AM vs. primarily midnight–4 AM? The closure vs delay distinction hinges on that timing.

collaboration.collaborationSummary: Agents reached consensus after 1 round(s) with 2.0% spread. Average probability: 8%.

alert.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 5:17AM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.areas: Mason; Lake; Osceola; Clare; Oceana; Newaygo; Mecosta; Isabella; Muskegon; Montcalm; Gratiot; Ottawa; Kent; Ionia; Clinton; Allegan; Barry; Eaton; Ingham; Van Buren; Kalamazoo; Calhoun; Jackson
alert.desc:
Occasional light snow will move through Southwest Lower Michigan this
morning. 3 to 5 hours of snow will occur at any one location.
Snowfall will range from trace amounts to possibly an inch or two
towards Lake Michigan. In the wake of the heavier snow a period of
freezing drizzle may occur, especially from mid morning through early
afternoon.

The main impact will be slowed travel this morning. Slick conditions will
develop due to the snowfall. Allow some extra travel time this
morning to reach your destination.

alert.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 30 at 4:15PM EST until February 2 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Grand Rapids MI
alert.desc:
* WHAT...Flooding along the Muskegon River remains possible due to
an ice jam.

* WHERE...A portion of west central Michigan, including the
following county, Newaygo.

* WHEN...Until 700 PM EST Monday.

* IMPACTS...Ice jams are notoriously unpredictable. Low-lying areas
along the Muskegon River that are prone to flooding may see
rapidly changing water levels as ice shifts and adjusts.

* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...
- At 408 PM EST, an ice jam remains in place on the Muskegon
river in southern Newaygo County. The river gauge at Newaygo
shows water levels remaining at minor flood stage as of
Friday afternoon. As temperatures warm this weekend, water
levels should continue to slowly fall. Shorter periods of
rising and falling water levels are expected with any shifts
in the ice.
- As the river freezes up, ice can restrict the flow of the
river and cause rises and falls in water level. While
flooding associated with freeze up ice jams is typically
minor, conditions can change rapidly and unpredictably.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Newaygo.
- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
alert.instruction:
Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law
enforcement. Respect any road closures in the area.
